elements.text: Hello, Jo. I’m guessing I’m not quite the Doctor you were
expecting.
CRASH IN (JON PERTWEE) DOCTOR WHO THEME.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 6
4. EXT. BEACH. DELPHIN ISLE.
ESTABLISH CRASHING OF THE WAVES.
(MURMURING TO HIMSELF, CONFUSED) Out there... They came from out there... We shouldn’t have... shouldn’t have—
LEE ENFIELD RIFLES ARE COCKED NEARBY. GENTLE FOOTSTEPS OF WINGFORD ACROSS SAND.
(APPROACHING. CALMLY) It’s all right, Hedgerton. My men aren’t going to open fire. Not unless I tell them to. We’re just here to take you back. You want to come back, don’t you?
I... I don’t know. I’m... I’m...
Confused?
Yes... That’s it. Confused.
Of course you are, old chap. These are difficult times. No need to worry, though. We’ll get you sorted. Come along.
Come along?
Back to the base. Remember, it’s all in the interests of National Security.
All... in the... interests of... of... of...
(PROMPTING GENTLY) National Security. Remember?
National Security. Yes. I remember.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 7
Good. Good, there’s a good chap. Now come on, take my hand. That’s it.
FOOTSTEPS ON SAND AS THEY LEAVE.
(LIKE A MANTRA) All in the interests of National Security. All in the interests of National Security. All in the interests of National Security.
THROUGH THIS, THEIR FOOTSTEPS ON SAND AS THEY WALK AWAY.
(CALMLY, OVER THIS) There, there. That’s it. Well done. Everything’s going to be all right.
MUSIC: EVERYTHING *ISN’T* ALL RIGHT.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 8
5. INT. UNIT HO. DOCTOR’S LABORATORY.
But you’re not... I mean. What do you mean, ‘not quite the Doctor I was expecting’?
I mean... Actually, I’m not sure what I mean. I don’t even know what’s happened.
Oh, I get it.
Get what?
It’s what happened before, isn’t it?
What happened before?
When there were two of you in the TARDIS and another one on the scanner. You know, the old one with the long white hair and the one with a sort of Beatles haircu—
Ah. Yes, I remember that.
I thought there were only three of you. You mean there are actually four of you?
Well... seven, at least.
Seven?
So far. I’m number seven.
So where are the others?
Just me. No sign of the others.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 9
Is this the Time Lords again? Is there some sort of crisis in space or something?
I don’t know.
You don’t know? How do I know you’re telling the truth?
Ah, but that’s just it. You don’t.
FOOTSTEPS APPROACH AS CORNELIUS ENTERS.
Ah, Doctor, there you are.
You recognise me?
Of course.
(MUTTERS) You’re one up on me, then.
I beg your pardon?
Nothing.
Doctor. My name is Captain Cornelius. His Brittanic Majesty’s Security Services require your presence.
Do they indeed.
While you’re here, you’re under British jurisdiction.
‘While I’m here’?
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 10
(IGNORING HIM) You have no choice. I have orders to take you and Miss Grant to a secure location. I expect Miss Grant has explained.
Er no... we’ve had other pressing matters to—
There’s nothing much to explain. (POINTEDLY) It’s alla bit ‘hush, hush’ apparently.
Jo, what’s going on?
I’ve no idea. The Brigadier’s in Geneva. Mike Yates was in command, but apparently he, Sergeant Benton and everyone else have been shipped out and replaced by— SOLDIERS IN FULL KIT COME JOGGING IN.
. this lot!
All right, carry on, Sergeant Wilkins. Escort these two to the helicopter.
And what if we don’t want to be escorted to your helicopter?
RIFLES ARE COCKED.
MUSIC: A NOTE OF DANGER. UNDERSCORE BEGINS.
You’re not serious!
Deadly, Miss Grant. It’s a matter of Natio—
National Security. So you said.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 11
I think he means it, Jo. We’d better do as he says.
THEY ARE BUSTLED OUT OF THE ROOM.
MUSIC: SINISTER CRESCENDO.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 12
6. EXT. UNIT HO. (CONTINUOUS
THE HELICOPTER ENGINE IS STILL RUNNING, ROTAR BLADES WHOOSHING. THE NOISE GETS CLOSER AS WE MOVE WITH THE DOCTOR AND JO.
THEY SPEAK CLOSE TOGETHER, BUT STILL HAVE TO RAISE THEIR VOICES OVER THE DIN.
Looks like a Westland Whirlwind...
What does?
The helicopter. Interesting.
Really? I’m more interested in whether or not you’re who you say you are.
And I’m also interested in why you didn’t voice your suspicions about me to Captain Cornelius.
Because... well, I suppose I trust him even less than I trust you.
I’1ll take that as a compliment, Jo.
(NOT HAPPY) Hmmn...
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 13
7. INT. UNIT HO. DOCTOR’S LABORATORY. (CONTINUOUS
HELICOPTER SOUND OUTSIDE. COMMS BLEEP.
Yes, we’ve refuelled and they’re boarding the helicopter.
STRANGE, DISTORTED NOISE FROM HIS ‘WALKIE-TALKIE’.
(AS IF REPLYING) Yes, I’m going to scan it now.
THE SOUND OF HIM TAKING A SMALL DEVICE FROM HIS POCKET. A FEW HI-TECH-SOUNDING CONTROLS ARE PRESSED. THE WARBLE OF
A SHORT SCANNING SOUND. A FEW BLEEPS OF CONFIRMATION.
It’s confirmed. We’ve found it. It’s the TARDIS all right.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 14
8. INT. HELICOPTER. ENGINE RUNNING BUT PRE-TAKE-OFF.
LATER IN FLIGHT.
FOOTSTEPS (OF CORNELIUS) CLAMBER IN. DOOR SLAMS SHUT. ALL SPEAK ABOVE THE DIN OF THE HELICOPTER.
Make sure they’re secured, Sergeant.
What took you so long?
(SHOUTS TO PILOT) Immediate take-off, pilot!
CUT TO EXTERIOR PERSPECTIVE AS HELICOPTER TAKES OFF.
CROSS-FADE BACK TO INTERIOR.
Hey... you?
Me? Don’t you mean, ‘Hey, Doctor’?
Huh. Look down there. Look.
Now I wonder what that’s for...
Captain?
Yes, Miss Grant?
There’s a lorry arriving at UNIT HQ down there. What’s it for?
I think it’s time we... er, restricted your view. Put the hoods on them.
What? Aargh—
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 15
SOUNDS OF DISCOMFORT AS HOODS ARE PUT OVER THEIR HEADS
Sorry about this, but I’m afraid it’s necessary. We can’t allow you to see where you’re going.
(MUFFLED THROUGH HOOD) How thoughtful of you. We wouldn’t want to become a risk to National Security, would we?
Quite. Now sit back and enjoy the ride. It’s going to take a while.
(MUFFLED THROUGH HOOD) A while? What if we get
claustrophobic?
(WRY CHUCKLE) Just remember, it’s for King and country!
(TO HIMSELF) King... ? Interesting.
CROSS-FADE TO EXTERIOR AS HELICOPTER SWOOPS OFF INTO THE DISTANCE.
MUSIC: PASSING OF TIME, WITH SINISTER UNDERTONES.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 16
9. INT. HEDGERTON’S ROOM. DELPHIN UNDERGROUND BASE.
THE DISTINCTIVE DEEP THROB OF AIR CONDITIONING. (WE WILL ALWAYS KNOW WE’RE IN THE BASE WHEN WE HEAR THIS. )
KNOCK ON DOOR.
(WAKES UP. HE’S STILL A LITTLE CONFUSED, BUT A BIT RECOVERED) Er... come in.
DOOR OPENS.
(ALL CHARM) Sorry, Hedgerton. Did I disturb you?
Wh— ? Er, no, it’s all right, Commander, I ex...
Oh, now I did, didn’t I? You were asleep.
Well...
Sorry about that, old chap. I just wanted to pop by and check up on you. See if you were all right. You’re important to us, you know. To the vital work we’re doing here on Delphin.
(VAGUE) Vital work? Oh, yes, yes, of course.
You’re our engineer. You’re pivotal to the plan. And don’t worry, your work will soon be over.
Will it?
Oh yes. Absolutely. Just one last push. Now, what you need is a nice visit to Level Zero-One.
(SOME DAWNING DREAD) Level Zero-One?
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 17
(ENCOURAGING) Yes. It’1ll do you the world of good. Just what you need.
Just... what I... I need?
Yes. You have your little rest, then I’1l send a couple of my chaps to come and get you, all right?
Rest... Yes.. yes, of course. Level Zero-One.
Get some rest. I’ll see you later.
THE DOOR OPENS AND WINGFORD LEAVES.
(MURMURING) Rest... Level Zero-One, level Zero-One, level zero-One...
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 18
10. INT. HELICOPTER. IN FLIGHT.
BEGIN ON EXTERIOR PERSPECTIVE OF HELICOPTER APPROACHING OVER SEA.
CROSS-FADE TO INTERIOR.
DOCTOR AND JO’S SPEECH IS MUFFLED BY THE HOODS. THEIR CONVERSATION IS CONFIDENTIAL IN TONE. HEADS TOGETHER.
(GENTLY) Jo? Jo...
(WAKING UP) Um? Sorry, I fell asleep. Did they drug us or something?
I don’t think so. It’s just the dark and the droning of the rotar-blades.. sends you to sleep.
So you’ve been awake?
Oh yes.
How long have we been travelling?
Just about three and a half hours.
How do you know that?
I have an infallible sense of time, Jo. And I also know we’re about to land.
How come?

The Westland Whirlwind helicopter has a maximum reach of just over 300 miles. Its top speed is 86 miles per hour, and we’ve certainly been travelling at top speed. So if we've been flying for about three and a half hours, we’ll have to land soon... Or crash into the sea.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 19
The sea? How do you— ?
I can smell it.
(APPROACHING) All right, you two, you can stop gossiping now. We’re about to land.
You were right, D— Er, you were right.
You nearly called me Doctor.
Only nearly.. whoever you are. You still haven’t explained yourself—
Only because I don’t have an explanation, Jo.
CROSS-FADE TO EXTERNAL PERSPECTIVE. WAVES CRASHING ON ROCKS. THE HELICOPTER DESCENDS AND LANDS.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 20
11. EXT. DELPHIN ISLE. CLIFF TOP.
HELICOPTER ENGINE WINDS DOWN. SEA CRASHING ASHORE NEARBY. SEAGULLS. QUITE A WIND BLOWING.
DOORS OPEN. CORNELIUS CLAMBERS OUT.
Right, get them out. Hoods off!
HOODS BEING PULLED OFF.
Thank you. Where are we?
PAUSE.
Top secret?
Correct, Doctor.
You were right about the sea... er, Doctor.
Yes, I was, wasn’t I? You know, Captain Cornelius, I get the distinct feeling we’re on an island.
Do you now, sir?
Somewhere in British Territorial Waters... maybe in the North Sea?
(WITH A SMILE) I couldn’t possibly comment, sir.
Hmmm. No, I’m sure you couldn’t possibly.
So, where to now? Are you just going to let us freeze to death on a cliff-top?
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 21
Time’s getting on. We’ve got some accommodation for you down in the village.
Village? What village?
You'll see. It’s not far off. This way, there’s a track
down here.
MUSIC: ‘HAUNTING ISLAND THEME’ TRANSITIONAL.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 22
12. EXT. DELPHIN VILLAGE. EVENING.
SOLDIERS, CORNELIUS, DOCTOR AND JO WALKING ALONG A TRACK. SHELTERED, NO WIND NOW. SEAGULLS IN BACKGROUND.
(CONFIDENTIALLY) I think you’re right about this being an island. I can’t see any coastline in the distance.
(CONFIDENTIALLY) No, neither can I. Just the sea. Mind you, it is starting to get dark now.
Here we are, Doctor! Up ahead!
Ah yes. Very picturesque.
Where are you taking us?
Down the hill, straight along the quayside. The local pub.
You flew us all this way just to buy us a drink?
(AMUSED) Huh, in a way, Miss Grant. Yes.
Quite a fleet of small boats moored in the harbour, Captain. Must be a thriving fishing industry here.
Er... perhaps.

Perhaps? What sort of answer is that? Are you obsessed with secrecy when it comes to any information? What if we want to buy you a drink in the pub? Will that be too ‘hush-hush’ for you to tell us what you want?
Just along here, Miss Grant.
A FEW MORE FOOTSTEPS, THEN THEY COME A HALT.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 23
(READING) ‘The Delphin Arms’. (BEAT) Looks very warm and inviting. Lovely glow from the fire inside.
Yes. Commander Wingford was keen for you to get a taste of the local hospitality before you join us in the base tomorrow.
There’s a base here, then, is there?
Of course, Miss Grant. Yes.
What sort of base— ? Oh, don’t tell me, a top secret one.
Naturally.
And we're staying the night in this pub?
Yes.
(INTRIGUED) Captain, if our presence was so urgently required... Why are you wasting our time with ‘local hospitality’?
AWKWARD PAUSE.
MUSIC: DISTURBING.
Captain?
Commander Wingford’s orders, Miss. Simple as that. In you
go. HE OPENS THE PUB DOOR.
SOME GENTLE HUBBUB WAFTS FROM INSIDE. (WILDTRACK)
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 24
Thank you, Captain. You won’t be joining us for a drink?
No, Doctor. But my men and I shan’t be far away.
That sounds a bit like a threat.
(SMILES) Does it? Enjoy yourselves.
Thank you...
CUT TO...
elements.character: THEY GO IN AND DOOR CLOSES

elements.text: Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 25
elements.character: THEY GO IN AND DOOR CLOSES

elements.text: 13. INT. DELPHIN ARMS PUB. CONTINUOUS.
(CALLING FROM THE BAR) Come in, don’t be shy now!
GENERAL GOOD NATURED LAUGHTER FROM THE SMALL GATHERING.
(TO JEREMIAH) Oh, thank you!
(SOTTO) This is just... a bit weird. Bringing us all this way.. to stay in a pub.
(SOTTO) And I’11 tell you something else that’s a bit ‘weird’.
(SOTTO) What?
(SOTTO) I think our Captain Cornelius was wearing make-
up.
(SOTTO) Make-up?
Come on, now!
(SOTTO) When I spoke to him at the door, with the light from the pub shining on him.. There was a line where his skin colour changed, just below his collar.
(SOTTO) Um... I’m not sure what that proves...
(SOTTO) Me neither.
(CALLING FROM BAR) Come on. No meandering. Come over and
have a pint of our finest. Food’s on.
DOCTOR AND JO APPROACH THE BAR.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 26
You were expecting us, were you?
(EMERGING) Course we were! The Commander said we were to make a fuss of you. Make you feel at home.
But we’re not at home, Miss er... ?
Call me Claire. And this is my husband, Jeremiah. We’re the landlord and landlady of the Delphin Arms.
(DEADPAN) And there we were, wondering why you were standing behind the bar.
AWKWARD PAUSE.
(SUDDENLY LAUGHS) Ah, very good. Very funny. And you two are... ?
Didn’t the commander tell you?
No. Just said two very important [sic] VIPs from the mainland would be staying.
‘Mainland’, you were right. This is an island.
That’s right. Delphin Island.
(DEADPAN) Oh, they named it after your pub.
No.. It’s the other way round, dear.
Oh yes... of course.
(SOTTO) Doctor, what are you—?
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 27
(SOTTO) Just a little irony test, Jo. And you just called me ‘Doctor’.
Wha— ? Oh, well, I didn’t mean to.
MUSIC: MEANWHILE
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 28
14. EXT. QUAYSIDE. JUST OUTSIDE PUB.
SOME HUBBUB FROM THE PUB CAN BE HEARD, MUFFLED IN THE BACKGROUND.
COMMS BLEEP.
(RESPONDING) Cornelius. Go ahead.
(DISTORT) Are they happy?
Relatively. The Doctor seems... suspicious.
(DISTORT) They should be happier after some social interaction, a hearty meal and a good night’s sleep.
Any news from London?
(DISTORT) All security protocols are still active. There shouldn’t be any trouble before we’re ready. Keep an eye on the pub, Cornelius.
Will do. Out.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 29
15. INT. DELPHIN ARMS.
PULLING TWO PINTS.
Now then, here’s a pint of best for you both.
FULL GLASSES PLONKED ON BAR DURING THE FOLLOWING.
Drink up now. It’s our best.
Is it now? Er.. well, thank you very much.
Um, I’m not really much of a beer drinker, actually, could I-— ?
Come along, Jo... When in Rome.
But—
(SOTTO) Best put them at their ease about us.
Oh... er, well... Yes, of course. Thank you. (SHE TAKES A SIP. IT’S REVOLTING) Er... it’s...
(SIPPING SIMULTANEOUSLY. HE ALSO FINDS IT REVOLTING. LYING) Lovely! Really lovely. (POINTEDLY) Isn’t it, Jo?
TAKES ANOTHER SIP AND GAGS, COUGHING
JEREMIAH & CLAIRE:
LAUGH HEARTILY
(LAUGHING) Oh, it’s a strong one and no mistakin’!
Ooh, it certainly is. Now, what about that food, my dear?
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 30
(GOING TO GET IT) Coming right up. You two sit yerselves down.
(TAKES ANOTHER SIP AND COUGHS, GAGGING) Yes... delicious!
PEOPLE IN THE PUB: WILDTRACK — ALL LAUGH
JEREMIAH & CLAIRE:
LAUGH
GENERAL PUB HUBBUB CONTINUES UNDER...
(SOTTO, TO THE DOCTOR) Is it just me or is this beer— ?
(SOTTO, TO JO) Rancid? Rotten and sour. Don’t drink any
more, but keep smiling.
(SOTTO, TO THE DOCTOR) Let’s hope the food’s better.
(SOTTO, TO JO) Hmm, let’s hope so. (ALOUD) Let’s sit
down. I’m starving.
(ALOUD) Mmm, me too! Let’s sit down here, shall we?
CHAIRS PULLED OUT AND THEY SIT.
CLAIRE IS APPROACHING WITH PLATES.
Now then, here you go, my lovelies. The best food on offer. A real Delphin special for you.
PLATES ARE PLONKED DOWN ON THE TABLES.
(CLEARLY IT LOOKS AWFUL) Well... er, that looks... um.
Delicious! Let’s tuck in, Jo!
DOCTOR PICKS UP KNIFE AND FORK.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs
There, you get that down yer. You must be fai
What makes you think that?
Well, they said, didn’t they?
Didn’t who?
The people at the base.
Oh yes. The people at the base. Of course.
Page 31
r starvin’.
They said you’d been on a long journey. Eat up now.
KNIFE/FORK SOUND. DOCTOR TAKES A MOUTHFUL.
(CHEWING. IT’S BEARABLE) Mmm. Lovely, thank you.
CLAIRE MOVES OFF BACK TO THE BAR.
(MOVING OFF) I’1ll go and make sure your rooms for you.
Thank you! (SOTTO) Eat up, Jo.
(SOTTO) Is it really ‘lovely’?
(SOTTO) It’s... edible.
KNIFE/FORK SOUND.
(CHEWING) Mmm... great. (SOTTO, TO DOCTOR) Just ‘edible’... and it’s not very warm. What is it? tinned food.
are ready
about Looks like
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 32
(SOTTO, TO JO) Yes, bully beef, tinned potatoes and carrots, all cooked to imperfection.
(CALLING OVER) You enjoyin’ that, are you?
Oh yes, it’s... it’s the best meal we’ve had since we got here.
Oh... well, that’s good to hear.
Yes, isn’t it?
(SOTTO) Doctor, what’s the matter with them?
(SOTTO) You called me Doctor again.
(SOTTO, BUT CROSS WITH HIM) Oh, never mind that! But there is something wrong with them, isn’t there?
(SOTTO) I’m not sure, Jo, I’m not sure. Just eat as much as you can, then we’ll make our excuses and go up to our rooms.
(SOTTO, CHEWING) I’m ready to make my excuses now.
(SOTTO, CHEWING, AMUSED) Yes, I know what you mean.
FADE OUT WITH TRANSITIONAL MUSIC (‘HAUNTING ISLAND THEME REPRISE’). TIME PASSING.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 33
16. INT. DELPHIN ARMS. STAIRS. LATER.
FOOTSTEPS OF THE DOCTOR AND JO BEING LED UP THE STAIRS CLAIRE.
This way. Up here. Didn’t you bring any luggage?
Er.. no, we didn’t. Did you expect us to bring some?
Guests usually bring luggage.
We weren’t expecting to come here.
Oh, surprise, was it?
Do you get many guests?
(SHE REACHES THE LANDING) There we are. Now, your room there, Doctor. And this is your room here, Miss Grant.
You know our names.
Do I?
Well, you just said them.
Yes. You must have told me.
We didn’t.
You must have.
Yes.. we must have. Night, night, Jo. See you in the morning.
BY
is
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 34
HE OPENS HIS DOOR AND STEPS INSIDE HIS ROOM. THE DOOR CLOSES BEHIND HIM.
Night. (SOTTO) Whoever you are.
What was that, my dear?
Nothing. (SIGHS) Well, good night then... Claire.
You see. You know my name. We must’ve introduced ourselves.
If you say so.
PAUSE.
Something the matter, dear?
It’s very quiet.
Course it is, dear. We’re miles off the mainland here on Delphin. And it’s only a small island. Not much goes on here.
No, I mean... There’s no noise from the bar downstairs.
They must’ve all gone home.
Suddenly?
MUSIC: HAUNTING REPRISE...
Eh?
Never mind. Night.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 35
SHE OPENS DOOR AND GOES IN.
Night, night, Miss Grant.
WE HEAR CLAIRE HEADING OFF DOWNSTAIRS.
AS SHE HEADS DOWNSTAIRS, HUMS TUNELESSLY TO HERSELF
MUSIC FADES.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 36
17. INT. DELPHIN ARMS. JO’S BEDROOM. CONTINUOUS.
JO CLOSES HER DOOR. WE HEAR THE MUFFLED HUMMING FROM CLAIRE DRIFT OFF INTO THE DISTANCE WITH HER DESCENDING FOOTSTEPS.
EVENTUALLY, SILENCE FALLS. WE HEAR ONLY THE DISTANT SOUND OF THE HARBOUR. A LIGHT WIND BLOWS, RIGGING RATTLES. SOME GENTLE SEAWASH.
JO’S FOOTSTEPS ON CREAKY FLOORBOARDS.
SHE STOPS. WE HEAR A RUSTLE OF HER TAKING SOMETHING OUT OF HER POCKET. SOMETHING PLASTIC AND METAL (HER SECRET TRANSCEIVER - ABOUT THE SIZE OF AN ELECTRIC TOOTHBRUSH). A BUTTON CLICKS.
STATIC BURST.
(SOTTO) Emergency transmission. Setting coded scrambler.
A CLICK AND A STRANGE, DISTORTED SQUAWKING NOISE.
This is Greyhound Four to Greyhound Leader. Are you receiving me, over?
STATIC FOR A FEW SECONDS. (TO HERSELF, IMPATIENT) Oh, come on, Mike. Come on.
MUSIC: TENSION BUILDS...
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 37
18. INT. DELPHIN BASE. WINGFORD’S OFFICE.
THE DISTINCTIVE DEEP THROB OF AIR CONDITIONING. DOOR KNOCKS.
Come.
DOOR OPENS. FOOTSTEPS IN, STAND TO ATTENTION.
Sir!
Ah, Cornelius. Everything all right at the pub?
They went to bed a couple of hours ago. Not a peep out of them since.
I’m afraid you’re wrong about that, Captain. Seems the girl had a concealed transceiver on her. She’s attempted to use it once to contact Yates.
Did she make contact?
No. But she will. The officers at the holding location in London will have told him. We can’t prevent that. And it won't be long before she tries again. Yates will probably be waiting for her call.
A STRANGE BLEEPING SIGNAL.
That’1l be it.
A SWITCH FLICKS.
WE HEAR THE FOLLOWING ON SPEAKER.
(DISTORT) This is Greyhound Four to Greyhound Leader. Are
you receiving me, over?
STATIC BURST.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 38
(DISTORT) Greyhound Leader receiving. Coded scrambler engaged. Go ahead, Jo. Where are you?
(DISTORT) We’re on Delphin Island, apparently.
(DISTORT) Apparently? You and the Doctor?
CONTINUES IN NEXT SCENE
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 39
19. INT. DELPHIN ARMS. JO’S BEDROOM. CONTINUOUS.
(HESITATES) Er.. well...
(DISTORT) Jo? Jo, what’s the matter? Are you all right?
So far. Listen, Mike—
(DISTORT) What do you mean, so far? Jo? Where is this Delphin Island anyway? I’ve never heard of it.
Neither had I. Mike, where are you? What’s going on?
(DISTORT) London. Secure premises. There’s some kind of security flap on.
Yes, that’s what Cornelius told us.
(DISTORT) Cornelius? Who’s he?
The regular army officer who had us brought here. So you’ve no idea what all this is about?

(DISTORT) None at all. To be honest, it’s been really getting on my nerves. I’ve spent the last few hours here trying to get answers. But all I get in return is blank faces and lectures on National Security. I can’t even get in touch with the Brigadier. (BEAT) Look, Jo, how did you get to this island?
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 40
20. INT. DELPHIN BASE. WINGFORD’S OFFICE. CONTINUOUS.
THE DISTINCTIVE DEEP THROB OF AIR CONDITIONING.
(DISTORT) Well, there was a helicopter.
I think that’s enough.
(DISTORT) And... er, well the... the Doctor... (SHE THINKS BETTER OF GOING INTO THE WHOLE ‘DOCTOR ISN’T THE DOCTOR’ BUSINESS HERE) Er, he said we'd travelled about three hours.
Jam it?
Yes.
(OBEYING) Sir.
(DISTORT) So you were travelling for three hours and—
CUT OFF
CLICK OF SWITCH.
(DISTORT) Mike? Mike, can you hear me? Mike, come in. Come— (CUT OFF)
CLICK OF SWITCH. SPEAKER OFF.
You should have searched her, Cornelius.
[*m sorry, sir. 1 didn*t think=

It doesn’t matter now. They’ll feel reassured enough after the hospitality of the pub and a good night’s sleep, I’m sure of it. They’1ll soon acclimatise. And besides, there’s no immediate rush. We can’t proceed until the arrival of the vital component.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 41
Understood, sir.

MUSIC: MILITARY ACTION CRESCENDO.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 142
70. EXT. DELPHIN ISLE. QUAYSIDE.
THE DOCTOR AND JO ARE SUPPORTING HEDGERTON AS THEY WALK ALONG — QUITE A STRUGGLE. WINGFORD AND CORNELIUS ARE FOLLOWING.
THE EUROPAN IS BUZZING SOME WAY OFF OVERHEAD.
Keep moving! Come on, move!
STRUGGLING, GASPING
(EFFORT OF SUPPORTING HEDGERTON) Can’t you see Hedgerton is exhausted? We have to rest.
We cannot wait. You must keep moving.
(EFFORT OF SUPPORTING HEDGERTON) It’s all right, Jo... we're nearly there. The TARDIS is just up ahead.
(WEAK) I’m sorry... sorry to be such a nuisance.
It’s all right. Don’t you worry. (SOTTO) Doctor, he’s getting worse.
(SOTTO) The years are catching up with him. I know the feeling... (THEY’VE ARRIVED) Here we are.
A.. police telephone box?
(SOTTO) Doctor, we could just get in the TARDIS and leave. I know. Bad idea, right?

(SOTTO) I’ve been wondering what I’m doing here, Jo... somehow transplanted into the wrong part of my life. Maybe there’s something I’m supposed to do. Something I didn’t do before. Maybe this is a second chance.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 143
(SOTTO) Second chance? But if it’s in your own past, wouldn’t you remember it? Do you remember it?
(SOTTO) No... that’s what’s worrying me.
EUROPAN DESCENDS NOISLY AND HOVERS OVERHEAD.
It is time for you to enter your TARDIS. Our ship is now ready for take-off. All it needs is the energy from your ship.
A STRANGE, HUMMING SOUND. THE TARDIS IS GLOWING.
Doctor, what’s happening to the TARDIS? It’s... sort of... glowing.
Our power stacks have locked onto it.
Yes, but you won’t be able to take the power unless I release it. (BEAT) Well, am I right?
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 144
71. INT. EUROPAN SPACECRAFT.
CONTROLS OPERATED. NEGATIVE BLEEPS.
I am now on the command deck of our ship. It is as we suspected. We cannot simply take the power. The Doctor right.
is
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 145
72. EXT. DELPHIN ISLE. QUAYSIDE.
TARDIS IS STILL HUMMING WITH POWER.
You must enter your craft.
But you were trying to take the power without my permission, weren’t you? Don’t you realise how much suffering could have been avoided if you’d simply asked politely in the first place?
Doctor, you can’t help these creatures. You don’t know what they might do with this power.
She’s right. Will you simply leave this island... this planet?
Yes!
That’s what you say!
How can I be sure of that? You could do a lot of damage with energy from the TARDIS. You could use it for a weapon to destroy the human race.
There is no time for this. Wingford, Cornelius! Restrain the female!
JO IS ROUGHLY GRABBED.
Get off me! Ugh— ! Doctor, don’t let them force you to—
Shut up!
Kill her if the Doctor does not enter his craft
immediately.
GUN COCKS.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 146
(LAUNCHING HIMSELF FORWARD) No!
Get back, Hedgerton. (HITS HIM)
IMPACT.
GASPS IN PAIN AND FALLS
No! Leave him alone. Hedgerton... ?
Can’t you see how weak he is? You could’ve killed him.
One human looks much like another to us.
I wasn’t talking to you! Commander! Captain! Listen to me, do you see what’s happening to this man?
He’s dying.
Perhaps he should have died years ago. Perhaps you’re all long dead...
Just kept alive by that blue stuff of yours.
(SOME DAWNING REALIZATION) What... ? What do you mean?
(STRUGGLING TO RECALL) Blue... I remember... remember...
(WEAKLY) The effect is weakening... even for them... Wingford? Cornelius? Don’t you remember what happened? All those years ago?
All... all those years... I... I...
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 147
Kill the girl! That is an order! From the government!
(STRUGGLING) All government orders must be—
Wingford! Cornelius! Look at that creature! Up there!
Look!
Since when did the government look like that!?!
MUSIC: MOMENT OF REALISATION.
(GASPING IN SHOCK) No! What— ? That thing!
(HORRIFIED) What is that creature?!?
Quickly, everyone, into the TARDIS!
Come on! All of you!
HEDGERTON IS STRUGGLING TO HIS FEET.
All of us? In there?
Come on, Jo, help me push them in!
JO, CORNELIUS, WINGFORD, DOCTOR, HEDGERTON:
NOISES OF EFFORT AND ‘BEING PUSHED
FOOTSTEPS SCUFF. TARDIS DOOR CREAKS OPEN.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 148
73. INT. TARDIS. CONTROL ROOM. STATIONARY.
DOOR OPENS/CLOSES AS THEY ALL ENTER. (NB. BACKGROUND AND CONTROL EFFECTS ARE PERTWEE TARDIS - REF THE THREE DOCTORS )
What's... what’s going on? Where are we? (STARTING TO SOUND WEAKER) Where... ?
This is incredible... (STARTING TO SOUND WEAKER) Incredible...
Never mind all that! (HE’S AT THE CONTROLS) Now then...
VARIOUS BLEEPS OF DOCTOR OPERATING CONTROLS.
Never mind... ? Have I gone mad?
So what are we going to do, Doctor? Are we going to leave?
A BLEEPING.
There’s a communication coming in through the scanner.
STATIC CLEARS ON SCANNER.
(DISTORT) Doctor. Our fate is in your hands. Our ship is ready for take-off. All we need is the power from your craft.
Well you’re not going to get it— are they, Doctor? Doctor?
PAUSE.
And anyway, a taskforce from UNIT is on its way to stop you.
Jo?
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 149
I managed to get through to Mike Yates. He should be on his way by now.
On his way? With a taskforce?
Well... yes.. He said he was going to muster as big a force as he could.
But why? What did you tell him?
Well... I don’t know. I thought.. I mean, they’re going to attack us, these things, aren’t they?
(LAMENTING) Oh, Jo..
(DISTORT) You think you know these humans so well, Doctor. You are an apologist for their fear and their brutality. Yet now you see how they intend to destroy us.
What about what you did to the people of this island!?!
(DISTORT) We fought to survive in the face of their naked aggression. We were fighting for the survival of our race.
Survival?
(DISTORT) We are the last of our people. Our planet will be dead by now. Our mission was to find another world.
Yes! You came to invade us!
I don’t think so, Jo.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 150
(DISTORT) Not this planet, with its corrosive atmosphere and its savage inhabitants. We hoped that our destiny would be out there... beyond this solar system.
So.. you don’t want to invade... or destroy us?
(DISTORT) No.
Oh no... But if Mike arrives and attacks—
You’ve got to stop him, Jo. Do you still have your radio?
Yes... (FINDING IT IN HER POCKET) Yes, I have. (CLICK) Greyhound Four to Greyhound Leader. Are you receiving me, over?
STRANGE LOUD STATIC.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 151
74. INT. HELICOPTER. IN FLIGHT.
START ON EXTERIOR PERSPECTIVE AS FOUR OR FIVE HELICOPTERS WHOOSH TOWARDS US. CROSS-FADE QUICKLY TO INTERIOR.
THE STRANGE STATIC NOISE AND GARBLED REPEAT OF JO’S CALL.
This is Greyhound Leader. We cannot read you. Jo? Jo, is that you? We’re nearly there! We’1ll be with you soon! Hold on! If you can hear me, hold on! Help’s on the way.
CLICKS RADIO OFF.
Right, sounds like they’re in trouble. Get the machine guns ready to fire.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 152
75. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM. STATIONARY.
CONTROLS ON THE TARDIS BEING OPERATED. STRANGE STATIC.
(FRUSTRATED) It’s no good— Doctor, what are you doing?
I’m going to try to give the Europans the power they need.
But if that ship takes off.. I mean, it’s buried underground, isn’t it? Won’t it smash through the island or something? Won’t that kill all those people who are— ?
(VERY WEAK NOW) As the Doctor said... we should have all died years ago... And without that... that secretion, we’re all dying now. Perhaps we’re already dead. Dead and just still walking.
Maybe, maybe not. But we can’t condemn everyone on this island to die when that underground base gets destroyed. That’s—
Inhuman? You’re right, Jo. As inhuman as the treatment the humans gave their alien visitors 30 years ago.
So.. what are you saying? Two wrongs make a right? My Doctor would never have agreed with that.
I know he wouldn’t. But then, perhaps that’s why I’m here.
To wipe out the people of Delphin Isle?
Or to save the last survivors of an entire species. Or do you want me to let them die here in a hail of bullets from Mike Yates and his army?
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 153
But if I can get through to Mike—
But can you get through to him? Can you?
CLICK.
Greyhound Four to Greyhound Leader. Come in.
STRANGE STATIC.
The power signal from the Europan ship is blocking the frequency. You’ll never get through.
Then... (TO THE EUROPAN) then shut off your stupid power Signal!
(DISTORT) We cannot. The ignition sequence is primed and ready. Doctor, we must receive the power now. It is our only chance of survival.
Very well. I’m activating power feed from the TARDIS’s engines now.
HE FLIPS A SEQUENCE OF CONTROLS. A HUM OF POWER FROM THE CONSOLE BEGINS. IT STARTS RISING IN PITCH THROUGHOUT THE FOLLOWING.
No, Doctor! You mustn’t!
(SO VERY WEAK NOW) Jo... Jo...
Hedgerton?
Look... look at Wingford and Cornelius... Look at them.
Oh my God.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 154
Both dead. Aged to death. They were older than me, you see. I was hardly more than a boy. Everyone on the island must have died years ago.
But you can’t be sure. You’re still alive.
Not for much longer, I fear.
But there may be others. Others who were as young as you.
No, Jo. I don’t think so.
We can’t just assume that.
The Doctor’s right. We did something terrible here... A race of aliens that meant us no harm.. And we made their lives into a living hell.
(DISTORT) Power building. Stacks initiating. Primary engine drive engaging.
Steady... steady! You’re draining too much power too fast.
(DISTORT) We cannot stop now. The primary drive thrusters need more power.
WARNING ALARM SOUNDS.
Oh no...
Doctor? Something’s gone wrong, hasn’t it?
I forgot... This version of the TARDIS pre-dates certain... modifications I made.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 155
What does that mean?
It means the old girl won’t be able to regenerate her power fast enough. The Europan ship will take every last drop from her... She’1ll die.
The TARDIS will die?
Yes.
You can’t let them do that. The TARDIS is too important to you. You just got it fixed again!
Is the TARDIS more important than the freedom and survival of a whole race?
What? No! You can’t think like that.

I didn’t know why I was here, in this wrong body, in this wrong era... But maybe I do now. Maybe it really is to correct something I didn’t get right before. If only I knew who was behind this... friend or foe— then I could be sure of what I should do.
THE TARDIS ROCKS AND STARTS TO GROAN. A CIRCUIT EXPLODES. A DEEP RUMBLE.
(DISTORT) We are lifting off, Doctor! Thank you!
Good-bye! Good luck! (TO HIMSELF) And good-bye, old girl... This is as good a way for you to go as any...
THE POWER DRAINS RAISES TO A PAINFULLY HIGH LEVEL. CIRCUITS EXPLODE.
No, Doctor! No! My Doctor would never do this! You can’t! And what will happen to you?
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 156
To me?
If the TARDIS dies now.. will there even be you? A seventh version of the Doctor? Won’t this change your history?
Perhaps... or put it on the right track. Maybe that’s why I’m here. To repair history. My own history.
This can’t be right, Doctor! You can’t destroy the TARDIS! I won’t let you!
FRANTIC FLICKING OF SWITCHES. BLEEPS OF CONTROLS.
Jo! Jo, what are you doing? Stop that! No!
(DISTORT) Power cut off! Engines stalling!
Jo, what have you done?!?
A HUGE EXPLOSION. CUT TO SILENCE.
HOLD. THEN SLOWLY FADE UP ON...
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 157
76. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM. STATIONARY. LATER.
JUST THE QUIET HUM OF THE TARDIS.
(SLOWLY REGAINS CONSCIOUSNESS. GROGGY) Doctor... ? Doctor... ? Where... ?
(CLOSE) Jo!
(SHE WAKES WITH A START) Hedgerton? What’s going on? It’s all gone quiet. Doctor? He’s gone.
He went outside?
A DEEP, RUMBLING, CRUNCHING OF AN EARTHQUAKE OUTSIDE.
Oh no... (SHE GETS UP AND RUNS, OPENING THE DOOR) Doctor!
Doctor!!!
DOOR OPENG...
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 158
77. EXT. DELPHIN ISLE. CRUMBLING.
THE DRAMATIC SOUNDS OF THE ISLAND FALLING APART. BUILDINGS CRASHING TO THE GROUND. HILLS SUBSIDING. ROCKS CRASHING INTO THE SEA.
JO EXITS THE TARDIS.
The place is falling apart! Falling into the sea.
You were right about what would happen.
Then... they took off.. And destroyed the island.
No. You cut off the power. It created an engine imbalance and their ship exploded.
Oh. And I didn’t save the island.

I think the Europans had weakened its structure. Probably mining it for minerals on a molecular level. This place is as brittle as the crust of a salt lake. One shock to its core was all that was needed.
I’m sorry about the.. what did you call them? Europans?
Yes. The last survivors from a moon of Jupiter. There was life on your doorstep all this time. And now they’ve been snuffed out.
And... It’s my fault. But I did it to save you. To save the TARDIS.
You had the best of motives, Jo. I know that.
I’m not sure if that’s good enough. I kept trying to think what ‘my Doctor’ would have done.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 159

I am your Doctor, Jo... just with the benefit of a few more centuries’ wisdom. But... (SIGHS) This was an impossible Situation. There was no right course of action. And don’t blame yourself. It was the fault of.. the worst of human behaviour. What happened here back in 1951.
So.. Do you think you’ll stay here, or will I get my own Doctor back? Don’t tell me... You don’t know.
I have no idea, Jo. But if things do go back to normal and the timelines reset.. I dare say you won’t even remember my being here.
BUZZ OF EUROPANS APPROACHING FAST.
EUROPAN LEADER & EUROPAN:
AGGRESSIVE SHRIEKS
Look, Doctor! They survived!
They must have ejected or something.
You betrayed us, Doctor! Condemned us to death, just as your precious humans did!
No! It was my fault. You were going to destroy the Doctor’s TARDIS.. destroy his future! And any survivors on the island, I couldn’t let—
There are no human survivors! They have all died!
And we too will die. But you will die with us!
Jo, get back to the TARDIS! QUICKLY!!!
EUROPAN LEADER & EUROPAN:
SHRIEK WITH EFFORT AS THEY SQUIRT THEIR SECRETIONS
A GUSHING, UNPLEASANT SQUIRT OF SECRETION.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 160
(ENGULFED) Aaargh!
Doctor!
HELCOPTER GUNSHIPS SUDDENLY SWOOP IN. CONCENTRATED GUNFIRE. UNPLEASANT-SOUNDING IMPACTS ON THE EUROPANS THEY ARE STRAFED.
EUROPAN LEADER & EUROPAN:
SHRIEK AS THEY DIE
EUROPANS CRASH TO THE GROUND, SQUELCH/CRUNCH. HELICOPTER HOVERS IN CLOSE.
(ON LOUD HAILER) Jo! Jo! Are you all right? Jo?
HELICOPTER GETS CLOSER AND CLOSER.
MUSIC: PASSING OF TIME.
CROSS-FADE TO...
AS
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 161
78. EXT. DELPHIN ISLE. THE REMNANTS. LATER.
IN BACKGROUND, THE ISLAND IS CRUMBLING. HELICOPTERS LANDING.
FOREGROUND...
SQUELCH OF SECRETION AS JO TRIES TO WASH IT OFF THE DOCTOR.
Argh, this stuff, stings.. Doctor? Doctor, are you— ?
YATES HAS BEEN RUNNING OVER DURING THIS.
(ARRIVING, OUT OF BREATH) Jo! Jo... Is that the Doctor under that blue stuff? Is he— ?
I don’t know.
ANOTHER SQUELCH AS SHE BRUSHES MORE OFF HIM.
GROANS, SEMI-CONSCIOUS
What’s been going on here, exactly?
It’s... a bit of a long story, Mike. Thirty years in the making.
Tell me about it... We discovered about thirty years of alien infiltration in that London secure location.
Really?
Seems whatever had been going on here... they had spies or
something right inside UNIT and the government for years. That’s how they were able to declare a security alert and get us all shipped out.
GROANS AGAIN
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 162
Doctor?
Jo?
Seems as though the Doc’s going to be all right.
ROCKS NEARBY CRASH INTO THE SEA.
This island’s falling into the sea. We’d better get out of here soon. (SUDDENLY NOTICING SOMETHING) Hey, who’s that?
FOOTSTEPS APPROACH.
Jo?
(DELIGHTED) Hedgerton. You’re still okay.
It.. it would seem so. There’s life in the old dog yet, eh? Um... who’s that?
Captain Mike Yates. UNIT. Pleased to meet you, Mr Hedgerton. You’re a survivor, I take it—
No. Not you. That. Who’s that lying there in all that...
mush?
What do you mean? It’s... the Doctor.
But... he looks... different.
Does he? I hadn’t noticed. Are you sure?
MUSIC: MISTY REMEMBRANCE.
Doctor Who: The Defectors by Nicholas Briggs Page 163
(SUDDENLY UNSURE) Sure... ? I’m... No... No, I’m not sure at all now. I... Yes... that’s the Doctor. I.. I remember now.
There’s no mistaking the Doctor. Come on, Mike. Can you pick up the TARDIS with one of your helicopters?
Would the Doctor ever forgive me if I didn’t?
(CHUCKLES) No... No, he wouldn’t. Come on. Let’s get out of here.
CRASH IN PERTWEE ERA THEME.
